node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.text: The number of working-age people in China is shrinking. Could this threaten the country’s rise as an economic superpower? Credit: Eyevine

node.title: China’s economy: what’s its weak spot?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of text that says 'Books & arts The best and worst ways to tackle linguistic sexism'.

node.text:
English has a long tradition of wrangling over its lack of a gender-neutral pronoun.⁠
⁠
More recently some have argued for a generic singular “they”, which has been employed in this way for centuries. But conservatives insist that it is illogical.⁠
⁠
As the debate about gender-neutral pronouns rumbles on, people have invented words to fit the bill: hesh, hizzer, herm and others.⁠
⁠
French feminists have used interposed dots to denote gender-neutral words. But click the link in our bio to read why linguistic engineering need not always be so awkward.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @nicklowndes_illustrator

node.text:
“I think we do still have some leverage.” On “The Economist Asks” podcast, General Sir Nick Carter, the chief of the British defence staff, says pressure can still be exerted on the Taliban to govern Afghanistan in an inclusive way.⁠
⁠
While Afghans face the reality of Taliban rule, the nature of America’s withdrawal has cast a shadow over President Joe Biden’s presidency. Host Anne McElvoy asks General Carter if the Taliban he fought can change - and should the West now engage with its leaders?⁠
⁠
As his tenure ends and a succession race gets underway, we ask General Carter what the future of the West’s defence will look like. And, what is he most - and least - proud of?⁠
⁠
To hear more, click the link in our bio to listen to “The Economist Asks”

node.text:
House-building in the rich world, relative to population, has fallen by 50% since 1964.⁠
⁠
Low housing supply means higher prices, constraining cities’ growth and reducing productivity. One estimate suggests that building restrictions lowered American output growth by a third between the 1960s and 2009.⁠
⁠
Economists do not agree on much, but they do almost all think that a shortage of housing is a big drag on the economy.⁠
⁠
Yet although most housing experts want more building, few spend much time thinking about how to make this happen.⁠
⁠
Better solutions are needed—and focusing on planners and homeowners could help. To find out how tweaking economic incentives might boost housing supply, tap on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @sebasthibault

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of 3 people.

node.text:
Even republicans dread the death of Queen Elizabeth II. Not just because they’ll be disgusted by the sombre TV coverage and black-edged newspapers but because she represents Britain’s strongest living link with the post-war consensus that, in 2021, just about holds.⁠
⁠
Her death will carry a psychic shock. The Queen isn’t just a head of state and a fixture of the currency. Britons carry her image in their heads as well as their pockets.⁠
⁠
When she dies, we may almost hear a crack opening up between the past and the present. She will be a tough act to follow. ⁠
⁠
There have been plenty of other cases in history where a certain kind of bravery has been required to succeed an important figure. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read our guide to how people have coped when they have gone from understudy to leading role.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Jake Read⁠
Additional images: Getty, Shutterstock

node.text:
Something extraordinary is happening in the West: a new generation of progressives is reviving old methods that threaten liberal values.⁠
⁠
Modern versions of loyalty oaths and blasphemy laws are being espoused, often by people who call themselves liberals. ⁠
⁠
In Restoration England, Oxford University burned the works of Hobbes and Milton. Today, young publishers try to get controversial books “cancelled”. ⁠
⁠
The new confessional state enforces ideological conformity by expelling heretics from their jobs, a practice that traditional liberals shed much blood trying to eradicate.⁠
⁠
Think the expulsion of heretics and the banning of books in the West is all in the past? Tap the link in our bio to read why you should think again. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: israelgevargas

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Jamaica. May be an image of 3 people, child, people sitting, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
Jean "Binta" Breeze became the ﬁrst and one of the few female performers of Dub in the world—putting lines of poetry over a reggae beat. ⁠
⁠
The radio was one of many voices in her head that told her what to do, sometimes ﬁercely, sometimes kindly. The poem that brought her to people’s attention, “Riddym Ravings” in 1988, was written out of her schizophrenia, as she begged the doctors in hospital to help.⁠
⁠
She mixed in rhythms from jazz and mento, Jamaican folk music, and, for quieter offerings, took blues out of her sleeve. She spoke for all the working-class women inhabiting her head, until the whole female third world clamoured in her too.⁠
⁠
She adopted “Binta” in the Rasta years of her 20s, as a west African name meaning “daughter of”. Daughter of the wind. That was where she belonged after death, not with roots and worms. ⁠
⁠
Jean "Binta" Breeze died on August 4th, aged 65. Tap the link in our bio to read our obituary.⁠
⁠
Credit: Tehron Royes

node.text:
Twenty years ago America set out to reshape the world order after the attacks of September 11th. ⁠
⁠
Today it is easy to conclude that its foreign policy has been abandoned on a runway at Kabul airport.⁠
⁠
Some will see the fiasco in Afghanistan as proof of American decline. That is going too far. For all America’s flaws, many facets of its power are intact.⁠
⁠
Its share of global GDP, at 25%, is roughly what it was in the 1990s. It is still technologically and militarily preeminent. It has a strong interest in an open world.⁠
⁠
America’s strategy can be retooled for the 21st century, provided the right lessons are drawn from the post-9/11 era. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read one of our cover leaders this week, which assesses America’s global standing, twenty years after the assault on the twin towers.⁠
⁠
Cover credit: The Economist

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Afghanistan. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'The cost of misogyny Societies that treat women badly are poorer and less stable'.

node.text:
As a group that champions violent misogyny is taking over Afghanistan, it is worth studying how the most sexist societies work.⁠
⁠
In rich, liberal countries, the idea of the male kinship group as the basic unit of society faded long ago. Elsewhere it is surprisingly common, and not just in Afghanistan.⁠
⁠
The obstacles females face begin in the womb. Thanks to sex-selective abortion and neglect, at least 130m of them are missing from the world’s population.⁠
⁠
That means many men are doomed to remain single; and frustrated single men can be dangerous.⁠
⁠
Oppressing women not only hurts women; it also hurts men. To read why it makes societies less stable, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
⁠Why are scientists deliberately infecting volunteers with covid-19?⁠
⁠
Human trials are a valuable part of medical research. The controlled environment of a lab allows scientists to collect information about how diseases work more quickly than relying on messy and uncertain data from the real world.⁠
⁠
Human challenge trials (HCTs) for covid-19 have been discussed since the early days of the pandemic. But only Britain has allowed them to go ahead.⁠
⁠
The results from the first trial are expected soon. They will include details on the course of infection, the effectiveness of different tests, how much exposure to the virus is necessary to infect someone, and how useful masks are in preventing transmission.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why, despite this promised bounty of valuable data on the disease, HCTs for covid-19 remain controversial. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @nadihaf

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and skyscraper.

node.text:
⁠Two books grapple with the impact of the September 11th on America. Both authors agree that the attacks, and their aftermath, defined the 21st century’s geopolitics—but their accounts are very different.⁠
⁠
In “Wildland”, Evan Osnos argues that the attacks inaugurated a period of “American fury”. At its best, his book has an appealing shaggy-dog quality, as Mr Osnos listens to people tell stories of their lives in the two decades since the cataclysm.⁠
⁠
But, character sketches aside, it will tell most readers very little that they did not already know.⁠
⁠
“Reign of Terror”, by contrast, will make readers see the past 20 years differently. Its author, longtime national-security correspondent Spencer Ackerman, argues that three things shaped America’s response to 9/11: xenophobia, norm-destruction and failure in Afghanistan and Iraq.⁠
⁠
To read why the attacks of September 11th can be seen as America’s last unifying moment, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Amy Sancetta, File

node.text:
“The world doesn’t wait for America to sort out its domestic challenges.” Zanny Minton Beddoes, The Economist’s editor-in-chief, tells our “Checks and Balance” podcast that the Biden administration is wrong to deprioritise foreign policy.⁠
⁠
America set out to reshape the world order after the attacks of September 11th. Today it is easy to conclude that its foreign policy has been abandoned on a runway at Kabul airport. Is the era of American interventionism over? ⁠
⁠
The Economist's James Bennet traces Joe Biden’s shifting views on foreign wars. We look back to the origins of humanitarian interventionism in Bosnia. And, Anne-Marie Slaughter, former aide to Barack Obama and author of “Renewal: From Crisis to Transformation in Our Lives, Work and Politics”, tells us how American power might work in the future.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to our podcast on democracy in America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"The The world after 9/11 meant that American Muslims were careful in ways they had not needed to be before Farah Pandith'.

node.text:
Scars and emotional damage run deep for American Muslims who experienced the anger, prejudice, isolation, violence and societal unease following 9/11, says Farah Pandith.⁠
⁠
Writing for The Economist, the Muslim former American official recounts "the period of fear, bigotry and name-calling" that American Muslims experienced before 9/11, and argues that while the community has enjoyed many triumphs since, it has been "a hard 20 years".⁠
⁠
"Although on the surface, American Muslims have fared well since 9/11, below the successes and behind the smiles is something else," Ms Pandith argues.⁠
⁠
"For those who grew up as American Muslims after 9/11, they never knew a time when they were not questioned about their faith, culture or heritage," she adds. ⁠
⁠
"American Muslims continue to this day to think about who they are, how they belong to the whole, how to raise their kids and what they can do to make sure they are safe. Whereas before, American Muslims were not forced to consider those aspects of identity, in post 9/11 America they had to."⁠
⁠
To read why Ms Pandith believes that the success of American Muslims is built on pain and resilience, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @dan.will
